sm::eod::io::InetAddress

InetAddress Class Reference

#include <inetaddress.h>

List of all members.

Detailed Description

An InetAddress consists of an IP address, and a port number.

This class is NOT thread-safe, since there is a static _address_init bool which is used and not protected by a mutex. This may only cause unexpected behaviour if two threads happen to try to construct the first InetAddress at the same time. In this case, the local address table may be populated twice.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

InetAddress ( int  port = 0  )  [explicit]

Constructs the internet address of the local host.

If no port number is specified, zero is used indicating that the port number can be the next available.

Exceptions:
SocketError Error initializing networking

InetAddress ( int  port,
const std::string &  host 
)

The host string can be a hostname or a dotted IP number.

If a dotted IP address is provided, but no hostname could be resolved, the hostname is set to the dotted address string. If a hostname is provided but could not be resolved, the address reverts to the local host.

Exceptions:
SocketError Error initializing networking

InetAddress ( int  port,
int  adapter 
)

Constructs the internet address on the given port number and local adapter.

Exceptions:
SocketError Error initializing networking

InetAddress ( const InetAddress &  rhs  ) 

Constructs a copy.

bool setHost ( const std::string &  host  ) 

The host string can be a hostname or a dotted IP number.

If a dotted IP address is provided, but no hostname could be resolved, the hostname is set to the dotted address string. If a hostname is provided but could not be resolved, the address reverts to the local host.

Parameters:
host contains the hostname as a string containing the dns name of dotted IP number.
Returns:
true if the address was ok

void setPort ( int  portnum  ) 

Sets the portnum of the address.

Parameters:
portnum Should be a valid unsigned short number. Negative port numbers will be set to 0. Port numbers that are too big will be truncated to the largest 16 bit port number. There may be restrictions imposed by your OS on what port numbers can be used
